column4: where is it defined that when i press alt+f2 the console switches to /dev/tty2 ? i mean how can i map key that if i press lets say alt+f12 it doesnt switch the console to /dev/tty12 but to /dev/my_own_tty ?
i imagine the workings of alt+ctrl+f1-7 are defined somewhere very deep down in the operating system, maybe even in the kernel
i mean just alt+f1-6 actually - the ones that switch virtual consoles
to be exact, ctrl+alt+f1-7 change to different consoles, the x-server happens to run on the 7th :)

however, i may well be incorrect with my assertion that the effect of ctrl+alt+f1-7 is written into the kernel. i remember hearing that ctrl-alt-del for example is now outside of the kernel in a configuration file. maybe i can find it...
nrx: that is unusual. almost all wireless cards support wep-encryption. are you sure you are entering the right sort of key? (hexidecimal, 128bit for example)
nrx: knowing that other pcs are working fine should make it easier to narrow the problem down :)
nrx: what sort of wireless card do you have? maybe the linux driver has some problems.
[nrx] : that is unusual
somone said to read keymaps man page
[nrx] : have you tried a packet sniffer? something like ethereal? maybe that can tell you what's going wrong
looking at the manpage that seems to be exactly what you're looking for :)
[nrx] : the packet sniffer under ubuntu is called "wireshark". this will allow you to record the traffic between your laptop and your router while they are negotiating a dhcp-lease
[nrx] : then it will allow you to see all packets transmitted between the router and the laptop while negotiating an entry in the routing table of the router :)
looks like that... but i still dont know how its happened that alt+f3 is bint to the /etc/event.d/tty3 event :(   $ dumpkeys | grep tty gives me zero result
it is unusual that alt+f3 does anything. are you sure you don't mean ctrl+alt+f3?
[nrx] : the way i see this, without more knowledge, nothing much can be done. how do you know the laptop isn't connected to the router?
[nrx] : have you tried setting your ip-address manually?
[nrx] : and entering essid and password using iwconfig?
[nrx] : that may well unfortunately be necessary, but it can be done quite easily :)
[nrx] : i'm afraid i don't know anything about the errors.
thanks hjmills :)
probably yes :)
